verses.roman:
ei ūniśa artha karilu, āge śuna āra
'ātma'-śabde 'deha' kahe,--cāri artha tāra

synonyms: ei—these; ūniśa—nineteen; artha—meanings; karilu—I have done; āge—ahead; śuna—hear; āra—more; ātma-śabde—by the word ātma; deha—the body; kahe—is understood; cāri artha—four meanings; tāra—of that.
translation: "I have already explained nineteen different meanings. Now please hear further meanings. The word ātma also refers to the body, and this can be taken in four ways.

purport.content: The four divisions are (1) aupādika-brahma-deha, the material body considered as Brahman with designations (vide verse 212), (2) karma-niṣṭha yājñikera karma-deha, the body engaged in ritualistic ceremonies of the Vedic injunctions (vide verse 214), (3) tapo-deha, the body engaged in austerities and penances (vide verse 216), and (4) sarva-kāma-deha, the body engaged for the satisfaction of all kinds of material desires (vide verse 218).
